Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Interaction of Smart Materials for Transparent, Self-regulating Building Skins

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the United States 50 percent of all energy produced is consumed by buildings and 75 percent of all electrical power is used for the operations of buildings. The functions of building skins are traditionally limited to be passive in nature such as serving as thermal and moisture barriers and modulators of sunlight. There is a need for innovative strategies to reduce energy consumption in buildings. The objective of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to harness the inherent properties of smart materials to explore the interaction of these materials and their potential to be used in active and multifunctional building skins. Smart materials provide the opportunity to imbue building skins with more dynamic capabilities namely, to regulate functionalities such as gas exchange and purification (oxygen, carbon dioxide, and common urban air pollutants), to modulate porosity, to reduce thickness of thermal barriers, and to harvest energy and water from the air. If successful, it will address the resource, energy, and labor intensive infrastructure systems that currently serve a building's utility functionalities. This exploratory project will engage interdisciplinary student teams during design studios and workshops (a) to investigate the interaction of smart materials within innovative building skins, and (b) to fabricate and test these smart material interactions. A team of material scientists, engineers and architects will pursue this endeavor.

This exploratory project fundamentally rethinks the way buildings are designed and operated. It is envisioned that building systems that integrate their functionalities through self-monitoring and adjusting their properties and behaviors according to external environment to attain a desired outcome and drawing inspiration from physiological systems in the natural world. Smart materials, such as shape memory alloys, bi-metallic strips, stimuli-responsive polymers, dendritic or star polymers, and piezoelectric materials, will be explored for self-regulating behavior. The methodology will involve graduate and undergraduate students from the disciplines of Architecture and Materials Science and Engineering including students from underrepresented groups and offering significant benefits to them. The project will pursue research and test active, transparent and multifunctional building skin proto types using smart materials that can interact with and react to their environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes from the exploratory NSF-EAGER 1548243 "Interaction of Smart Materials for Transparent, Self-regulating Building" included the following: (a) We developed a design method for soft, lightweight, transparent, and self-transformable shell surfaces. Our technique includes laminating a soft and stretchable material called "EcoFlex" to a cut, temperature-responsive polymer. Our proposed hybrid-surface can transform from a very rigid to very flexible composite. The soft material allows the surface to stretch and the shape memory polymer to harden into place. (b) We discovered a novel method for producing responsiveness and promoting reversible shape-changing characteristics on a wooden surface by laminating an epoxy resin-based polymer onto kerfed wood. The outcome is a wooden surface with improved mechanical properties and self-transforming capacity. Wood as a sustainable and very commonly used material in architecture can become a vital part of adaptive design and smart material technologies through this technique. (c) We developed a method to create a temperature-responsive wood composite by making a viscous shape memory liquid and coating. In comparison to our laminating technique, the coating offered better control of the geometry and polymer ratio in our composite. The original shape of the composite does not need to be flat by this technique while we were able to control distributing the polymer across the surface. (d) We developed a method to make a temperature-responsive surface that can transform from a 2-dimensional plane surface to a 3-dimensional curvilinear surface. We applied the results of our study on kerfing algorithms to cut the shape memory polymer we fabricated in the lab. As a result, we were able to program shape memory behavior by controlling geometry through relief-cutting patterns--and glass transition temperature through chemical mixture ratios. The glass transition temperature determines the temperature that makes a polymer flexible and that allows it to return to its original shape. (e) We developed a lamination technique to produce a multi-layered shape memory polymer. Each layer can contain a polymer with different properties such as glass transition temperature, color, thickness, and level of flexibility. This technique offers great potential to create a multifunctional composite with greater capacity. Finally, (f) we identified and measured wind flow rates through nozzle shapes that could be embedded in a wall using smart materials that would self-regulate to optimal shapes to enhance cross-ventilation.

Recognizing the multiple potential approaches to development and testing of self-regulated buildings skins using smart materials, our team engaged 60 students (30 undergraduate and 30 graduate) during two semester-long design studios. During these semesters, interdisciplinary student teams developed seven geometric prototypes to inform incorporation of smart materials during a later phase and solicited feedback from building skin specialists at a culminating public competition and presentation. These prototypes have been photographically documented and compiled in two publications and websites. Concurrent to the studio semesters, the five PIs met weekly with a dedicated team ranging from 7 to 11 research students at a range of academic levels including PhD, masters, and undergraduate from architecture, construction science and materials science and engineering. Students and co-PIs engaged in research outside their laboratories, resulting in work made publicly available as follows: more than 12 conference proceedings, 2 peer-reviewed journal articles, 2 presentations, 2 website/blogs, 2 graduate-level theses, 1 forthcoming book chapter, and 1 documentary film short.
